Finally! Yes! I have been waiting for Crash Course Statistics since Hank Green told (in the video titled "Changes to our Patreon"), that, in 2018, Crash Course will introduce a course on Statistics! Yes! Finally! Of course, I had to wait for a long time, but, now, here it is! I thank John Green and Hank Green for starting Crash Course and adding so many new courses. I thank the staff of Crash Course for thinking about this and finally doing it. I thank the course hosters of each course in Crash Course for hosting the courses. I thank all of you! Please continue to make new courses and educate the next generation. You're videos are awesome. They mix learning and fun - something that other YouTube channels like TED-Ed, Kurzegsagt - In a nutshell, Thought Café, Life Noggin, SciShow ( including associated channels like SciShow Space) , Khan Academy, Minute Physics, Numberphile, etc have actually done so far, but, as always, every channel mentioned here has its own unique way of educating. So do you! I like the way you crack jokes between the episodes. I also like the way you explain stuff. I love the animation, too! I thank PBS Digital Studios, Thought Café (for the animation), and all the other organisations that have contributed a lot to Crash Course. I also like the music. You're videos have helped not only me, but all of us, a lot! You're awesome! Once again, thank you so much for the courses. Don't Forget To Be Awesome!

Great with a crash course on statistics. Since I read Kahnemanns Thinking fast, thinking slow, I thought that I should get better skills in thinking and understanding phenomena statistically, but also that it should be taught much more comprehensively in high school and college. Evolution has given us fast causal thinking, while it served all creatures well through the eons of evolution, it has been pivotal for overall fitness. Now we can’t help to see and search for causal connections, even where there aren’t any. Some phenomena and truths about the world are to be understood as statistical, as distributions and probabilities, but that understanding doesn’t come naturally, easily to us. But - where quick causal thinking has served us well, it might have become a liability if not for the individual then for society, while we too often believe to understand society, developments, traits and events in causal terms, when a statistical understanding would be more propitious : there is no malicious puppeteer causing and plotting against us, but rather randomness, distributions and probabilities.

There's a TED Talk done by a math professor named Arthur Benjamin who argues that the end-game of America's math curriculum should be changed from Calculus to Statistics. As wonderful as Calculus is, and as much as it should be learned by any college freshman in a whole number of degrees, it's not used by the majority of people in everyday life. Statistics, however, are. We use it everyday whether we actively know it or not, and knowing how it is used and abused is vital today more than ever. Personally, as someone who worked in Market Research for years, I am excited that CC has chosen to teach people about this because I would often wish people would consider just how important and influential statistics really are. To paraphrase Arthur,

I think it would be far more significant if everyone knew what two standard deviations from the mean means, and I mean it.

To claim that Statistics helps us find the "truth" is a dangerous claim. You're taking correlation and implying causation. Statistics don't tell us anything about the world, it makes smart observations of the world. Just like Science, Statistics and regression are about making a hypothesis based on data, and systematically disproving hypothesis' until we find the one most correct based on the data.

To claim statistics tells us the "truth" is to imply that somehow, there is a connection between meterological events and Strawberry-flavoured pop-tarts. When you word it like that it's ridiculous, but that's exactly the claim you made in this video. That is no truth, it's an observation about the weather, correlated with people's purchasing habits. I'll repeat it again for clarity, correlation != causation.
